g.text: . According to Munich Re, loss from about 100 significant events in 2018 for
Africa are estimated at 1.4 billion USD
While there are questions about the sufficienc
y of insurance products to address the losses and damages
related disasters, insurance can help to cover immediate needs directly, provide rapid
response and transfer financial risk in times of extreme crisis
and Zachmann 2015; Hermann et al. 2016; Wolfrom and Yokoi
UNESCAP 2017; Matias et al. 2018; UNECA 2018; Broberg and Hovani
. Commercial insurability is heavily driven by the
predictability of losses and the resulting ability to calculate insurance premium levels properly. Climate
change has become a major factor of increasing uncertainty. The
data in calculation of premium levels may be but a starting point given the likely need for upward
adjustment due to climate change and potential consequential economic damage. Different risk
yholders and insurers will create contrary assessments on premium levels and
also stresses the systemic effect of climate change on
insurers' business models and resulting availability of appropriate insurance products.
The conventional approach to such protective or hedging position has
classical insurance micro, meso and macro level schemes
insurance schemes such as index insurance and we
ather derivative approaches that cover individual’s
specific needs such as coverage for farm crops. Meso level insurance schemes, which primarily benefit
intermediary institutions, such as NGOs, credit union, financial institutions and farmer credit entiti
seek to reduce losses caused by credit default thereby ‘enhancing investment potential’, whereas macro
level insurance schemes ‘allow both insured and uninsured individuals to be compensated for damages
catastrophe bonds and weather derivatives etc. that transfer risk to capital market
Over the last decades, there have been a trend towards weather
insurance products based on predefined pay
out risk pooling instrument. It has gained favour
governments in developing regions such as Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific because it provides
reconstruction and reduces moral hazard. This ‘
financial resilience’ is also increasingly appealing to the
business sector, particularly MSMEs, in developing countries
To date, sovereign parametric climate r
isk pooling as a way of managing climate risk does not seem to
have much traction in developed countries and does not appear to be attractive to actors in the G
20 members are yet party to any climate risk pooling initiative
. However, international bilateral donors such as the USAID and the Foreign, Commonwealth &
evelopment Office (FCDO, formerly DfID), and the multilateral development banks, are all, to
different extent, supporters of the various climate risk pooling initiatives now operational in developing
As noted also in IPCC AR5, risk sharing and r
arrangements that shift economic risk from one party to another’
countries and regions is relatively advantageous when compar
ed to conventional insurance because of
the effective subsidizing of ‘affected regions’ using revenues from unaffected regions which involve
pooling among a large subset of countries
less costly than what an individual country or entity can achieve and disbursement is rapid and there
. The World Bank argues that the
experience with Pacific Catastrophe Risk Insurance Pilot (PCRIP) and Africa Risk Capacity risk
pooling (ARC) show saving of 50% in obtaining insurance cover f
